filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of America a Prophecy Copies B and I. Ten of the fourteen extant copies of America were printed in 1793, the date on its title plate. Copy I, now in the Huntington Library and Art Gallery, is from this printing. The eighteen plates of Copy I, like those of the other 1793 copies but unlike those of the later copies, were printed on two sides of the leaves, except for the frontispiece and title page (Plates 1 and 2), and left uncolored. The plates were printed in greenish-black ink; five lines at the end of the text on Plate 4 were masked and did not print, and Plate 13 is in its first state. Copy B was printed in 1795 with Copy A in the same brownish black ink on one side of the paper, with Plate 13 in its second state. Unlike Copy A, however, it is uncolored except for gray wash on the title plate. Now in the Morgan Library and Museum, Copy B has a very curious history. Its Plates 4 and 9, which were long assumed to be original, are in fact lithographic facsimiles from the mid 1870s produced to complete the copy. For a full technical description and history of this copy, see Joseph Viscomi, “Two Fake Blakes Revisited; One Dew-Smith Revealed.” Blake in Our Time: Essays in Honour of G. E. Bentley, Jr. Ed. Karen Mulhallen. Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2010. 35-78. Copies B and I join six other copies in the Archive, Copies E and F (1793), A (1795), M (c. 1807), and O (1821), which altogether represent the full printing history of this illuminated book.
America a Prophecy was the first of Blake's "Continental Prophecies," followed by Europe a Prophecy in 1794, executed in the same style and size but usually colored, and, in 1795, "Africa" and "Asia," two sections making up The Song of Los. Fine and important examples of all three works are in the Archive. Like all the illuminated books in the Archive, the text and images of America Copies B and I are fully searchable and are supported by the Archive's Compare feature. New protocols for transcription, which produce improved accuracy and fuller documentation in editors' notes, have been applied to Copies B and I and to all the America texts previously published.
With the publication of these two copies, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of 85 copies of Blake's nineteen illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. In addition to illuminated books, the Archive contains many important manuscripts and series of engravings, color printed drawings, tempera paintings, and water color drawings.
Due to recent security concerns related to Java browser plugins, the Archive has disabled its Java-based ImageSizer and Virtual Lightbox applications. Users can still view 100 and 300 dpi JPEG images as well as complete transcriptions for all works in the Archive including America Copies B and I. Text searching is also still available for all works in the Archive, and image searching remains available for all works except those in preview mode. In the coming months the Archive will implement redesigned pages that restore the features of ImageSizer and the Virtual Lightbox without the use of Java.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

illustration.illusobjdesc:
The design embodies the destructiveness of warfare.
In the middle distance is a stone wall with, on the right, the
fragments of a top carved with classical motifs. A great gap
appears to the left, and in this gap sits a giant winged figure.
He is nude and muscular, with prominent knees and feet and both
arms shackled and chained to the ground or to the remnants of the wall on which he
squats or sits. His legs are drawn up in an extremely contracted
posture, with his knees to his shoulders. His head is lowered and
rests on his knees; his face is not pictured. His hair is long and
curly. The contracted posture and lowered head suggest despair.
He may be Albion's Angel, the representative of the establishment
forces, or Orc, the personification of revolution. To the right
is a family group, all nude. A woman, very probably a mother,
sits on a fragment of the stone wall, legs crossed. Her hair is long and her
face expresses a brooding fear, despair, or simply exhaustion.
She holds in her lap a young child, probably male. He
faces forward but perhaps looks up toward the woman. His
(right?) knee is prominent. Another child, of uncertain gender,
leans against the woman's left thigh and hip and hides his or her
head below the woman's left arm. This figure's legs are crossed
at the ankles. We see this figure from behind. On the ground
below the woman is the haft of a broken sword, and further to the
left is a dismounted cannon. The sky is dominated by dark
clouds, perhaps of smoke.

AMERICA a PROPHECY,
Object 2 (Bentley 2, Erdman ii, Keynes ii)

illustration.illusobjdesc:
The lowest part of the design is formed of male
corpses stacked like cord wood. We see, on the first level of
the stack, the tops of the heads and horizontally-extended arms
of two rigid bodies lying prone. The next layer is a single
rigid body, lying supine, with his legs extended to the right and
his arms at his side. He faces up. Above him is a gowned woman
with long hair, lying on top of him with her left leg drawn up
and her right leg extended. She embraces the man around the neck
with her left arm. Her face, seen in profile, touches the dead
or dying man's face below her; she may be kissing him, trying to
resuscitate him, or simply mourning over him. Her mouth is partly open. The dark sky above
these figures contains a few diagonal white lines that may
indicate rain or sleet descending from the clouds above. These
large clouds bear the title, as though inscribed upon them, and
six figures. On the left, a gowned woman with long hair sits
with right leg extended before her and her left leg bent back
behind her. She faces and hunches over to the left, apparently
holding a book or tablet also being looked at or read by a gowned
child, probably male, with curly hair. He stands before the
woman and faces right, but is probably looking down at the book
or tablet. At least his right arm is extended horizontally and
may rest on the book or tablet. Behind the woman is another
figure, perhaps nude and female, sitting with legs extended and
her back leaning against the back of the woman. Although the
scale of the figures is uncertain, this may be a child or young
girl. Another group of three figures is on the right. An old,
bearded man with long hair sits facing to the right. He wears a
heavy gown and hunches over a book or tablet on his lap, at which
he appears to be looking and perhaps reading. His posture is
contracted, in contrast to the figure to the right—a nude female
hovering in the air. We see her from behind; her posture is
gracefully twisted. Her left arm is raised horizontally, her
right arm at 135 degrees. The index finger on her right hand
points upward. Her right leg is extended, her left drawn up. Her hair is
in a bun. Behind the old man is a nude male, youthful and facing
to the right although his body is turned to the left and leans
against the back of the old man. His legs are crossed and he
points upward and to the left with his right arm, hand, and
extended index finger at an angle of 135 degrees. His left arm
is bent and supported against the old man's back. Although these
two nude figures are much smaller than the old man, they are
probably not children but energetic representations of spiritual
states unperceived, or ignored, by the old man. The two large
figures with books or tablets have sometimes been identified as a
sibyl and a prophet. Alternatively, the male may be a
priest.

reading. She has sometimes been identified as a

The seated woman holds and appears to read a book or tablet in her lap.

A gowned child with curly hair, probably male,
stands before the seated woman. He faces right and apparently
looks at and perhaps reads the tablet or book held by the woman.
His right arm is raised horizontally and perhaps points to a
passage in the book or tablet.

Behind the large seated woman is another figure,
perhaps nude and female, sitting with legs extended and her back
leaning against the back of the woman. Although the scale of the
figures is uncertain, this may be a child or young girl. She
turns her head toward us. Her right arm dangles at her
side, and she may be pointing downward.

Right of the word "a" in the title inscription (line 2), an
old, bearded man with long hair sits facing to the right. He wears
a heavy gown and hunches over a book or tablet on his lap, at which
he appears to be looking and perhaps reading. He may be a prophet
or priest.
The seated old man holds and appears to read a book or tablet in his lap.

A nude female hovers in the air right of the old
man. We see her from behind; her body is gracefully twisted,
with her head facing to the left. Her left arm is raised
horizontally, her right at 135 degrees. The index finger on her
right hand points upward. Her right leg is extended, her left drawn up.
Her hair is in a bun.

Behind the old man is a nude male, youthful and
facing to the right although his body is turned to the left and
leans against the back of the old man. His legs are crossed and
he points upward and to the left with his right arm, hand, and
extended index finger at an angle of 135 degrees. His left arm
is bent and supported against the old man's back, against which
he leans. A lock of his (long?) hair drifts to the left.

The dark and stormy sky above the woman lying on the
corpses contains cloud outlines and diagonal white lines perhaps
representing rain or sleet. The angle of the rain or sleet
indicates a wind blowing from left to right.

The upper two-thirds of the plate contains cloud
outlines against a background of dark, stormy sky. Both the title words and associated
figures seem to float on these clouds or hover before them.

illustration.illusobjdesc:
Although the plate contains considerable text, it
appears as though the plate is treated as a single design
extending across the top one third, down the left margin, and
across the lower margin. A large tree, perhaps an oak, with
arching branches dominates the top left of the design. The
vegetation right and left of the large trunk may be separate
bushes. Below and to the right of its trunk is a large stone or
earthen bank (with a few tufts of grass) to which is shackled a
nude, youthful male by both hands and feet. His arms are spread
out horizontally on the rock, as if crucified; his legs are also
spread apart. His torso and neck are twisted, perhaps in pain;
he faces up. His mouth is open; he may be speaking or crying in
pain. His hair is curly; he is probably Orc, the spirit of
revolution here restrained. To the right are a nude male and
female, both standing. The female, with legs spread apart,
grasps her head with both hands, as if in mourning or despair.
We do not see her face, but her upper torso is twisted to the
left—toward the shackled youth. She may be Enitharmon, Orc's
mother. Further to the right, the male stands with legs spread
apart. His body faces us, but he turns his head to the left and
may be looking at the shackled youth. His arms, with elbows
bent, are raised over his head, with his hands raised, palms out,
and the fingers of both hands spread apart. His hair is spiky or
flame-like; his general expression is one of horror or grief.
His mouth is slightly open; he may be speaking or crying out in
sorrow. This may be Los, Orc's father. Alternatively, the
couple has been identified as Adam and Eve, or as the "Dark
virgin" and Urthona (another name for Los) mentioned on this
plate (lines 12, 2). The roots of the tree descend through the left
margin, perhaps taking on anthropomorphic shapes. At the end of
the roots, in the far lower left corner of the plate, sits or
squats a nude, youthful male in a severely contracted posture.
His legs are drawn up, with his head resting on his knees. He
faces forward, with a grim expression, and holds his crossed
hands over his ankles. His hair is curly or flame-like. This
may be another representation of Orc, as the personification of
underground forces of revolution now enclosed but with the
potential to break out. A reticulated worm, with six loops,
fills the lower margin. The loops suggest (although they do not
quite form) a spiral.

lg.l: The shadowy daughter of Urthona stood before red Orc,

When fourteen suns had faintly journey'd o'er his dark
abode;

His food she brought in iron baskets, his drink in cups
of iron;

Crown'd with a helmet & dark hair the nameless female
stood;

A quiver with its burning stores, a bow like that of
night,

When pestilence is shot from heaven; no other arms she
need:

Invulnerable tho' naked, save where clouds roll round
her loins,

Their awful folds in the dark air; silent she stood as
night;

For never from her iron tongue could voice or sound
arise;

But dumb till that dread day when Orc assay'd his
fierce embrace.In Copy I, the "c" in "embrace" at the end of line 11 printed very lightly and is difficult to see.

Dark virgin; said the hairy youth. thy father stern
abhorr'd;

Rivets my tenfold chains while still on high my spirit
soars;

Sometimes an eagle screaming in the sky, sometimes a
lion,

Stalking upon the mountains, & sometimes a whale I
lash
The raging fathomless abyss, anon a serpent folding

Around the pillars of Urthona, and round thy dark
limbs,

On the Canadian wilds I fold, feeble my spirit
folds.

For chaind beneath I rend these caverns; when thou
bringest food

I howl my joy: and my red eyes seek to behold thy
face

In vain! these clouds roll to & fro, & hide thee from
my sight.

physdesc.objnote:
Five lines of verse etched on the copperplate following line 17 were masked during printing in Copies B-F, H-M, R, and a. These lines were erased after printing in Copy G (Bentley page 94). These lines, printed in Copies A, N-Q, read:
The stern Bard ceas'd, asham'd of his own song; enrag'd he swung
His harp aloft sounding, then dash'd its shining frame against
A ruin'd pillar in glittring fragments; silent he turn'd away
And wander'd down the vales of Kent in sick & drear la-
mentings.

illustration.illusobjdesc:
Although containing a good deal of text, the plate
is treated almost as a full-page design, with pictorial motifs
filling the lower third of the plate and continuing up the left
margin. In the lower margin, a muscular nude youth with curly, flame-like hair seems to be rising out of the ground. His right knee
and foot are prominent; his hands are placed on the ground and
his arms, bent sharply at the elbows, seem to be pushing him
upward. He looks up and to the right. This is probably Orc. To
the left are a good many roots, as though we could see below the
surface of the earth. Above these roots is a large plant growing
up the left margin. It bears two large leaves and a long branch
that terminates in a grain tassel. To the left of this plant is
a vine that forms a long, vertical spiral. There are a few small
plants and tufts of grass right of the nude male and left and
right of the large plant.

In thunders ends the voice. Then Albions Angel wrathful
burnt

Beside the Stone of Night; and like the Eternal Lions
howl

In famine & war. reply'd. Art thou not Orc, who
serpent-form'd

Stands at the gate of Enitharmon to devour her
children;
Blasphemous Demon, Antichrist, hater of Dignities;

Lover of wild rebellion. and transgresser of Gods
Law;

Why dost thou come to Angels eyes in this terrific
form?

lg.l:
The terror answerd; I am Orc, wreath'd round the
accursed tree:

The times are ended; shadows pass the morning gins to
break;

The fiery joy, that Urizen perverted to ten
commands,

What night he led the starry hosts thro' the wide
wilderness:

That stony law I stamp to dust: and scatter religion
abroad

To the four winds as a torn book, & none shall gather
the leaves;

But they shall rot on desart sands, & consume in
bottomless deeps,

To make the desarts blossom, & the deeps shrink to
their fountains,

And to renew, the fiery joy, and burst the stony
roof.
That pale religious letchery, seeking Virginity,
May find it in a harlot, and in coarse-clad honesty

The undefil'd tho' ravish'd in her cradle night and
morn:

For every thing that lives is holy, life delights in
life;

Because the soul of sweet delight can never be
defil'd.

Fires inwrap the earthly globe, yet man is not
consumd;

Amidst the lustful fires he walks; his feet become
like brass,

His knees and thighs like silver, & his breast and
head like gold.

lg.l:
Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my Thirteen
Angels!

Loud howls the eternal Wolf! the eternal Lion lashes
his tail!

America is darkned; and my punishing Demons
terrified

Crouch howling before their caverns deep like skins
dry'd in the wind,

They cannot smite the wheat, nor quench the fatness of
the earth.

They cannot smite with sorrows, nor subdue the plow
and spade,

They cannot wall the city, nor moat round the castle
of princes,

They cannot bring the stubbed oak to overgrow the
hills.

For terrible men stand on the shores, & in their robes
I see

Children take shelter from the lightnings, there
stands Washington

And Paine and Warren with their foreheads reard
toward the east

But clouds obscure my aged sight. A vision from
afar!

Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my
thirteen Angels;

Ah vision from afar! Ah rebel form that rent the
ancient

Heavens! Eternal Viper self-renew'd, rolling in
cloudsBlake etched an exclamation mark after "Heavens," but in Copy I the vertical stroke was not inked, except for a bottom and top edge, and prints mostly as a blind embossment.

I see thee in thick clouds and darkness on America's
shore,

Writhing in pangs of abhorred birth; red flames the
crest rebellious

And eyes of death; the harlot womb oft opened in
vain

Heaves in enormous circles, now the times are
return'd upon thee,

Devourer of thy parent, now thy unutterable torment
renews.

Sound! sound! my loud war trumpets & alarm my
thirteen Angels,

Ah terrible birth! a young one bursting! where is the
weeping mouth?

And where the mother's milk? instead those
ever-hissing jaws

And parched lips drop with fresh gore; now roll thou
in the clouds

Thy mother lays her length outstretch'd upon the
shore beneath.

Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my
thirteen Angels!

Loud howls the eternal Wolf: the eternal Lion lashes
his tail!

lg.l:
Thus wept the Angel voice & as he wept the terrible
blasts

Of trumpets, blew a loud alarm across the Atlantic
deep.

No trumpets answer; no reply of clarions or of
fifes,

Silent the Colonies remain and refuse the loud
alarm.

On those vast shady hills between America & Albions
shore;

Now barr'd out by the Atlantic sea: call'd Atlantean
hills;

Because from their bright summits you may pass to the
Golden world.
An ancient palace, archetype of mighty Emperies,

Rears its immortal pinnacles, built in the forest of
God
By Ariston the king of beauty for his stolen bride,

Here on their magic seats the thirteen Angels sat
perturb'd,

For clouds from the Atlantic hover o'er the solemn

lg.l:
Fiery the Angels rose, & as they rose deep thunder
roll'd

Around their shores; indignant burning with the fires
of Orc

And Bostons Angel cried aloud as they flew
thro' the dark
night,

He cried; Why trembles honesty and like a
murderer,

Why seeks he refuge from the frowns of his immortal
station,

Must the generous tremble & leave his joy, to
the idle: to
the pestilence!

That mock him? who commanded this, what God! what
Angel!

To keep the gen'rous from experience till the
ungenerous

Are unrestraind performers of the energies of
nature;

Till pity is become a trade, and generosity a
science,

That men get rich by, & the sandy desart is giv'n to
the strong

What God is he, writes laws of peace, & clothes him
in a tempest

What pitying Angel lusts for tears, and fans himself
with sighs

What crawling villain preaches abstinence & wraps
himself

In fat of lambs? no more I follow, no more obedience
pay,

So cried he, rending off his robe & throwing down his
scepter.

In sight of Albions Guardian, and all the thirteen

streaks of red

Across the limbs of Albions Guardian, the
spotted plague smote
Bristols

And the Leprosy Londons Spirit, sickening all their
bands:

Albions Guardian writhed in torment on the eastern
sky

Pale quivring toward the brain his glimmering eyes,
teeth chattering

Howling & shuddering his legs quivering; convuls'd

Sick'ning lay Londons Guardian. and the ancient
miter'd York

Their heads on snowy hills, their ensigns sick'ning

The plagues creep on the burning winds driven by

And by the fierce Americans rushing together in the

their banners seard

With fires of hell, deform their ancient heavens with
shame & woe;

plagues.

his back & ribs;

And rough with black scales all his Angels fright
their ancient heavens

The doors of marriage are open, and the Priests in
rustling scales

Rush into reptile coverts, hiding from the fires of
Orc,

That play around the golden roofs in wreaths of
fierce desire,

Leaving the females naked and glowing with the lusts
of youth

For the female spirits of the dead pining in bonds of
religion;

Run from their fetters reddening, & in long drawn
arches sitting;

They feel the nerves of youth renew, and desires of
ancient times,

A giant figure, wearing a gown and probably female,
crouches on the ground in an extremely contracted posture. Her
legs are bent under her body and her upper body is bent forward
at a sharp angle over her legs. She faces right but her head faces down; her face is
covered by her right arm, bent at the elbow with the upper arm
raised. Apparently, her hands are together in an attitude of
prayer or supplication. Her long hair cascades below her right
elbow and down the right margin of the text, perhaps transformed
into a waterfall. Despair and crying are suggested by the
figure; perhaps we are to think of the waterfall as her tears.
The figure has been variously identified as a personification of
Earth (given the presence of other figures on her body) and even
as Urizen, in spite of the apparent gender. Seven figures stand
or sit on the giant's body. On her head is a seated figure,
facing right and holding (and apparently reading) a book or
tablet. On her back are two figures, one standing and facing
right. This apparently gowned figure holds a book or tablet in
her or his right hand. Just to the right is a kneeling figure,
with one leg extended back, and the right arm raised at 135
degrees. This figure may be looking up and supplicating or
praying. Below these two figures, and standing on the giant
figure's right upper thigh, is a tree with three branches (but no
leaves). Standing and leaning against this tree is a (probably
male) figure facing to the right. He wears a broad-brimmed hat
and holds and plays a pipe. Further down the giant's thigh are a
few forms that may be sheep lying (and sleeping?) on her body.
Thus, the piper is probably a shepherd. Below the piper, a very
small figure lies on the giant's calf, facing right. This too
may be a shepherd, given the presence of a few forms to the right
that may be lying (and sleeping?) sheep. Just to the left of the
giant's right foot is an embracing couple. The figure most
likely to be the female in this group is seated with at least one
leg bent at the knee, head facing down, and left arm raised
horizontally to embrace her companion. The man kneels on the
ground, facing right, with his right arm extended at 45 degrees
to touch the woman's left thigh. To the right of this couple,
and standing on the ground just beneath the giant's lower leg, a
stag runs or leaps to the right. The left portion of this design
above the text is a forest of at least four leafless trees.
Their trunks have anthropomorphic forms. We can also see some of
their roots near the left margin; one such root extends left of the
first nine lines of text in the left margin. The ground near the right margin apparently descends over a cliff.

figure; perhaps we are to think of the waterfall as her tears.
The figure has been variously identified as a personification of
Earth (given the presence of other figures on her body) and even
as Urizen, in spite of the apparent gender.

On the giant figure's head is a seated figure, probably gowned,
facing right and holding (and apparently reading) a book or
tablet.

On the giant figure's back are two figures, one
standing and facing right. This apparently gowned figure holds a
book or tablet in her or his right hand.

The figure seated on the giant's head holds (and apparently reads) a book or
tablet. The figure standing on the giant's back also holds a book or
tablet.

Just to the right of the figure standing on the
giant figure's back is a kneeling figure, with one leg extended
back, and the right arm raised at 135 degrees. This figure may
be looking up and supplicating or praying.

Standing on the giant figure's upper thigh and
leaning against a tree is a figure facing to the right. He wears
a broad-brimmed hat and holds and plays a pipe. The presence of
what may be sheep further to the right suggests that this is a
shepherd.

Standing on the giant figure's upper thigh and
leaning against a tree is a figure facing to the right. He wears
a broad-brimmed hat and holds and plays a pipe.

A very small figure lies on the giant's calf, facing
right. The figure props up its upper body with at least one arm. Given the presence of what may be sheep to the right,
this may be a shepherd.

Just to the left of the giant figure's right foot is
an embracing couple. The figure most likely to be the female in
this group is seated with at least one leg bent at the knee, head
facing down, and left arm raised horizontally to embrace her
companion.

The man in the embracing couple, left of the giant
figure's right foot, kneels on the ground, facing right, with his
right arm extended at 45 degrees to touch the woman's left
thigh.

On the ground beneath the giant figure's right lower
leg, a stag runs or leaps to the right.

The small objects lying on the giant figure's upper
leg, right of the small figure under a tree, may be a flock of
sheep.

The small objects lying on the giant figure's calf
may be a flock of sheep.

The giant figure's hair takes on the character of a
waterfall where it cascades into the upper right margin of the
text.

The left portion of the design above the text is a
forest of at least four leafless trees. Their trunks have
anthropomorphic forms. We can also see some of their roots near
the left margin; one such root extends along lines 1-9 in the left margin.
A small figure standing on the giant figure's upper thigh leans against a tree with branches but no leaves.
The odd forms on the horizon right of the giant figure suggest hills or more distant mountains. Alternatively, the form at the right margin may be the limbs of a tree.
The ground near the right margin apparently descends over a cliff.

lg.l:
Over the hills, the vales, the cities, rage the red
flames fierce;

The Heavens melted from north to south; and Urizen who
sat

Above all heavens in thunders wrap'd, emerg'd his
leprous head,

From out his holy shrine, his tears in deluge
piteous

Falling into the deep sublime! flag'd with grey-brow'd
snows

And thunderous visages, his jealous wings wav'd over
the deep;

Weeping in dismal howling woe he dark descended
howling

Around the smitten bands, clothed in tears & trembling
shudd'ring cold.

His stored snows he poured forth, and his icy
magazines

He open'd on the deep. and on the Atlantic sea white
shiv'ring.

Leprous his limbs, all over white, and hoary was his
visage,

Weeping in dismal howlings before the stern
Americans

Hiding the Demon red with clouds & cold mists from
the earth;

Till Angels & weak men twelve years should govern
o'er the strong;

And then their end should come, when France reciev'd
the Demons light.

Stiff shudderings shook the heav'nly thrones! France
Spain & Italy,

In terror view'd the bands of Albion, and the ancient
Guardians

Fainting upon the elements, smitten with their own
plagues

They slow advance to shut the five gates of their
law-built heaven

Filled with blasting fancies and with mildews of
despair

With fierce disease and lust, unable to stem the
fires of Orc;

But the five gates were consum'd, & their bolts and
hinges melted

And the fierce flames burnt round the
heavens, & round the abodes of
men
FINISThe word "FINIS" was etched in white line in the tail of the serpent at the bottom of the plate. In some other copies of *America*, such as Copies O and M, the word has been obscured by color.
